description.narrative: To achieve the Renewable Climate Goals, the Netherlands and other countries around the world will have to rely heavily on renewableenergy technologies, such as wind turbines, solar cells and batteries for energy storage. The Dutch government aims to reduce CO2 emissions by 95 percent by 2050. This has set targets for renewable energy production and plans for the construction of offshore windfarms as part of the country's energy mix. However, the increased dependence on wind energy in the Netherlands and worldwide will lead to a greater demand for the minerals needed to produce wind turbines. Metals such as copper and cobalt are essential and indispensable elements for building wind turbines. However, the extraction of these metals has been linked to human rights violations in countries such as Zambia and the DRC where ActionAid works. Women in Zambia have many negative consequences from copper mining, while cobalt has been linked to child labor in the DRC. In order to prevent the communities in which ActionAid cooperates from suffering more from the growing demand for raw materials for windmills, ActionAid (in collaboration with SOMO) has conducted two studies (HumanRights in Wind Turbine Supply Chains 2018 <(>&<)> update 2019) since 2018. We investigated the extent to which wind turbine manufacturers take action to prevent and address human rights violations and environmental damage, based on international guidelines, such as the OECD Guidelines and the UNGPs. Both investigations concluded that manufacturers are not yet doing enough to tackle human rights violations. We see realizing a covenant for this sector as a means to activate companies and to really commit to doing due diligence.

participating-org.narrative: ActionAid (formerly known as NIZA) supports people in developing countries to defend their rights. Including the right to food, education and to participate in decisions. Its goal is to help people in developing countries to work themselves out of poverty. It starts with good mapping of the problems together with the poorest. Then local projects are set up, always for the long term. Sometimesit is direct support - such as relief or agricultural tools - but the emphasis is always on structural improvements. ActionAid unites people, provides legal assistance and training to help people defend their rights and hold their own leaders to account. Many problems can not be resolved locally, but ask for better international regulation. In Europe and in the Netherlands they call on governments and businesses to change unfair policies with major implications for developing countries. In addition, they regularly call onthe public, for example by campaigning for specific issues.
